Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Interference Management for Visible Light Communications via Poisson Model

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Visible light communication (VLC) is emerging as a viable alternative wireless transmission technology that could potentially alleviate the spectrum scarcity problem. VLC uses ordinary light sources such as light emitting diodes (LEDs) as the communication medium, and superposes a high frequency on/off operation on top of light sources for data transmissions. Compared to radio communications, the advantages of VLC include several orders broader in bandwidth, very little regulatory restrictions, ubiquitous light sources, and higher level of security for transmissions. One of the main challenges in the design of VLC at the physical layer is the issue of interference caused by simultaneous transmissions of multiple sources due to diffusion of lights emitted from regular light sources. While interference management for the Gaussian model (valid for the strong background light noise regime) is relatively well understood, it is mostly unexplored for the Poisson model (valid for the low background light noise regime).

This project will design novel interference management techniques for VLC in the Poisson regime, analyze the corresponding transmission rates/throughputs for VLC, and develop information theoretic methodologies to characterize the fundamental communication limits on these transmission rates. The proposed research is expected to make substantial contributions to both applications and theory. On the application side, this project is anticipated to substantially advance our understanding of interference management for VLC, and provide important guidelines for designing high throughput and resource efficient VLC networks. On the theoretical level, the project will develop new stochastic calculus and information theoretic tools to advance our understanding of Poisson channels. The PIs will also use this project as a great platform to attract and train students from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Visible light communication (VLC) is emerging as a viable alternative wireless transmission technology that could potentially alleviate the spectrum scarcity problem. VLC uses ordinary light sources such as light emitting diodes (LEDs) as the communication medium, and superposes a high frequency on/off operation on top of light sources for data transmissions. Compared to radio communications, the advantages of VLC include several orders broader in bandwidth, very little regulatory restrictions, ubiquitous light sources, and higher level of security for transmissions. Poisson channel is a popular model for VLC. Compared with the well understood Gaussian channel for the radio spectrum, the Poisson channel brings signficant challenges. First, the Gaussian model for the radio spectrum is linear, while the Poisson model is nonlinear. Second, the input to the radio spectrum can be negative, while the input to the Poisson model is limited to be positive. Third, the channel model for the radio spectrum is analog input analog output, while the Poisson model is analog input digital output. In this project, to develop techniques to address these challenges, we investigated various communication scenarios motivated by the application of VLC. 

In the first major thrust, we study fading Poisson MIMO channel with varying dark currents under two scenarios of practical interests: one with no delay constraint and the other with a strict delay constraint. For both scenarios, we assume that the transmitter knows the dark current levels. This is a reasonable assumption because the dark current level here represents a statistic quantity but not the realization of the noise. Hence, the amount of feedback needed from the receiver to the transmitter is limited. For the case with no delay constraint, we establish the ergodic capacity, and characterize the corresponding optimal power allocation scheme as a function of the dark current levels that achieves the ergodic capacity. For the case with a strict delay constraint, our goal is to minimize the probability that the instantaneous achievable rate is less than a given threshold, i.e., the outage probability. Minimizing the outage probability directly is very challenging. In order to solve the problem, we study a number of related optimization problems. We first solve the maximum rate that a channel with a particular dark current can support. If the maximum rate is less than the target rate, we set all antennas to be off. If the maximum rate is larger than the target rate, we then find the minimum sum power such that the rate is the same as the target rate. Finally, we check whether the average of the reduced sum power satisfies the long-term power constraint or not and make appropriate further modifications. We show this procedure produces the optimal signaling scheme that minimizes the outage probability.

In the second major thrust, we study the Poisson MIMO multiple access channel (MAC). We first show that the complex continuous-time continuous-input discrete-output Poisson MAC can be converted to a discrete-time binary-input binary-output Poisson MAC. We further show that characterizing the sum-rate capacity of any given Poisson MIMO-MAC is equivalent to characterizing the sum-rate capacity of a carefully constructed Poisson SISO-MAC. For the Poisson SISO-MAC, if the channel is symmetric, the existing study shows that the mutual information between the inputs of multiple users and output is Schur concave. Using this useful property, one can reduce the characterization of the sum rate capacity of the symmetric Poisson multiuser channel to a single parameter optimization problem, as by Schur concavity the input parameters of all users should be the same. For the general case, however, we show that the mutual information function is not Schur concave anymore, and hence the existing technique is not applicable for our case. To solve this problem, we first show that the characterization of the sum rate capacity is equivalent to a multivariant convex optimization problem with inequality constraints. We then show that there are sixteen different cases depending on which constraints on the KKT conditions are active. We further show that among these sixteen cases, the solutions to thirteen cases cannot be optimal. We finally characterize the exact conditions under which the solution of each of the remaining three cases is optimal. Compared with the Gaussian channel and the symmetric Poisson channel, there is one significant new feature of the asymmetric Poisson channel. In particular, in the Gaussian channel and the symmetric Poisson channel, to achieve the sum rate capacity, all users should transmit simultaneously. However, for the asymmetric Poisson channel, we show that this is not true anymore. To achieve the sum rate capacity of the asymmetric Poisson channel, there are scenarios under which only a subset of users will transmit. We characterize the exact conditions under which it is optimal to only allow a subset of users to transmit.
